sn4.25:1.2: Amending Arati to Rati (“delight”), following the argument in Marcus Bingenheimer, Studies in Āgama Literature 4.5.
sn4.25:2.2: Mara’s fascination with the Buddha seems more than professional. He was taking it personally.
sn4.25:2.4: Apparently cow elephants were used to trap wild bulls.
sn4.25:3.4: At this point, Māra has given up hope.
sn4.25:6.5: They approach an unknown ascetic with an extravagant gesture of submission.
sn4.25:14.1: The Buddha’s responds more closely to the accusations than he did with her father. | This verse is quoted and discussed, and the Sutta cited by name as the “Maiden’s Questions” (kumāripañhā) at AN 10.26.
sn4.25:16.2: Bodhi notes that the Sanskrit parallels here have present tense tarati for the Pali’s aorist atari. I translate assuming present tense. | Here the five floods must be the five senses, against which the Buddha has proven himself immune. Delight wants to know how to transcend the mind.
sn4.25:17.2: The present participle asaṅkharāno is a unique form. The meaning is not entirely clear in this context. The commentary says it means not generating the three kinds of kamma that lead to rebirth.
sn4.25:25.1: Like the concluding verse of the previous Sutta, this must have been added by redactors.
